org.fluidity.composition

Interface ComponentContainer.Registry

  • Enclosing interface:
    ComponentContainer

    public static interface ComponentContainer.Registry
    Allows adding component bindings to a dependency injection container.

    The registry offers several ways to map an implementation to an interface in the host container. Which one you need depends on your requirements. These methods are mostly invoked from the bindComponents() method of your binding implementation.

    • To simply register a component implementation for its component interfaces, use bindComponent(). This is exactly what the org.fluidity.maven:composition-maven-plugin Maven plugin does for a @Component annotated class with no automatic = false setting so if this method is all you need then you should simply use the plugin instead of creating your own binding class.
    • To register an already instantiated component implementation for a component interface, use bindInstance(). If the implementation is annotated with @Component then its automatic parameter must be set to false.
    • To register a component implementation when some or all of its dependencies are - by design - not accessible in the same container, use isolateComponent() method and use the returned container's getRegistry() method to gain access to the registry in which to bind the hidden dependencies. If the implementation is annotated with @Component then its automatic parameter must be set to false.

    Usage

    • Populating transient containers: 
       private void someMethod() {

   // some component
   @Component(automatic = false)
   class MyComponentImpl implements MyComponent {
     …
   }

   // some list of bindings
   final ComponentContainer.Bindings bindings = new ComponentContainer.Bindings() {
     public void bindComponents(final ComponentContainer.Registry registry) {
       registry.bindComponent(MyComponentImpl.class);
       …
     }
   }

   // a container received from somewhere
   final ComponentContainer container = …;

   final OpenContainer child = container.makeChildContainer(bindings);

   // use the child to get a component instance
   final MyComponent component = child.getComponent(MyComponent.class);

   …
 }
    • Overriding bindings: as an alternative to using explicitly context dependent components as dependencies, you can elect to isolate the dependencies of a component from the rest of the container, even if some or all of those dependencies could otherwise be found in the container. 
       final class MyPackageBindings extends EmptyPackageBindings {
   public void bindComponents(final ComponentContainer.Registry registry) {

     // SomeComponentImpl will be visible in the global container
     final ComponentContainer.Registry isolated = registry.isolateComponent(SomeComponentImpl.class);

     // AlternateDependencyImpl will not be visible in the global container
     isolated.bindComponent(AlternateDependencyImpl.class);
   }
 }

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      <T> void bindComponent(Class<T> type, Class<? super T>... interfaces)
      If the given class is an interface, or if it represents a concrete class and its scope is set to any of its component interfaces, this method binds, in the container behind this registry, every component class whose scope is set to the given class, to their respective component interfaces.
      <T> void bindComponentGroup(Class<T> group, Class<? extends T>... types)
      Binds all elements of an ad-hoc component group.
      void bindFactory(ComponentFactory factory, Class<?>... interfaces)
      Binds a component factory instance to a list of component interfaces in the container behind this registry.
      <T> void bindInstance(T instance, Class<? super T>... interfaces)
      Binds a component instance to a list of component interfaces in the container behind this registry.
      <T> ComponentContainer.Registry isolateComponent(Class<T> type, Class<? super T>... interfaces)
      Binds a component class to a list of component interfaces behind this registry and allows, via the returned registry, the caller to add further bindings that will only be visible to the supplied component and each other.

    • Method Detail

      • bindComponent

        <T> void bindComponent(Class<T> type,
                       Class<? super T>... interfaces)
                throws ComponentContainer.BindingException
        If the given class is an interface, or if it represents a concrete class and its scope is set to any of its component interfaces, this method binds, in the container behind this registry, every component class whose scope is set to the given class, to their respective component interfaces.

        If the given class object represents a concrete class without its scope set to its component interface, this method binds, in the container behind this registry, that component class to its component interfaces.

        The component class will be instantiated on demand by the container when it resolves any of the provided component interfaces.

        The supplied component class may implement ComponentFactory, in which case the receiver must support the factory functionality as described in the ComponentFactory documentation.

        When the interfaces parameter is empty, the component interfaces of the bound component will be determined by the algorithm documented at Components.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the component class to bind.
        Parameters:
        type - the component class.
        interfaces - optional list of interfaces that should resolve to the supplied component class.
        Throws:
        ComponentContainer.BindingException - when component registration fails.

      • bindInstance

        <T> void bindInstance(T instance,
                      Class<? super T>... interfaces)
               throws ComponentContainer.BindingException
        Binds a component instance to a list of component interfaces in the container behind this registry. Use this method when you have no control over the instantiation of a class as in case of third party tools handing you the component, but you still want to make the instances available for components in the container to depend on.

        The supplied component instance may be a ComponentFactory instance, in which case the receiver must support the factory functionality as described in the ComponentFactory documentation.

        When the interfaces parameter is empty, the list of interfaces that resolve to the component will be determined by the algorithm documented at Components.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the component to bind.
        Parameters:
        instance - the component instance.
        interfaces - optional list of interfaces that should resolve to the supplied component class.
        Throws:
        ComponentContainer.BindingException - when component registration fails.

      • bindComponentGroup

        <T> void bindComponentGroup(Class<T> group,
                            Class<? extends T>... types)
        Binds all elements of an ad-hoc component group. The group interface need not be annotated with @ComponentGroup.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the group interface type to bind.
        Parameters:
        group - the component group to bind the elements of.
        types - the elements of the group.

      • bindFactory

        void bindFactory(ComponentFactory factory,
                 Class<?>... interfaces)
          throws ComponentContainer.BindingException
        Binds a component factory instance to a list of component interfaces in the container behind this registry. Use this method when the list component interfaces that the factory can provide an implementation for is computed at run time.

        The receiver must support the factory functionality as described in the ComponentFactory documentation.

        When the interfaces parameter is empty, the list of interfaces that resolve to the component will be determined by the algorithm documented at Components.

        Parameters:
        factory - the component factory instance.
        interfaces - optional list of interfaces that should resolve to the supplied component class.
        Throws:
        ComponentContainer.BindingException - when component registration fails.

      • isolateComponent

        <T> ComponentContainer.Registry isolateComponent(Class<T> type,
                                                 Class<? super T>... interfaces)
                                          throws ComponentContainer.BindingException
        Binds a component class to a list of component interfaces behind this registry and allows, via the returned registry, the caller to add further bindings that will only be visible to the supplied component and each other. These bindings can, for the supplied component, override bindings in the container behind this registry.

        When the interfaces parameter is empty, the list of interfaces that resolve to the component will be determined by the algorithm documented at Components.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the component to isolate.
        Parameters:
        type - the component whose dependencies the child container will resolve.
        interfaces - the interfaces that the returned container should be able resolve through this container.
        Returns:
        the registry for the linked child container, never null.
        Throws:
        ComponentContainer.BindingException - when component registration fails.
